Three former undergraduates at the University of Mississippi will have to start their college educations all over again at another institution as the State of Mississippi has stripped their degrees following an investigation into an alleged cheating ring PERIOD The states Board of Trustees for Institutions of Higher Learning IHL voted to take away the three degrees during their annual fall meeting in Columbus on Oct PERIOD  PERIOD Dr PERIOD Pamela Smith assistant commissioner of public affairs and development for the IHL says the matter was 

According to IHL Board President Bryce Griffis the body consulted its attorneys in the matter PERIOD

 Smith said 

The IHL Board is the only body with the power to give and revoke academic degrees granted by Mississippi public universities according to Smith PERIOD 

Smith said that the students involved were not given the opportunity to make their case to the IHL board but that they should have been during the investigation at UM PERIOD

Jeff Alford a spokesman for UM said 

According to Alford eight students and one instructor were involved in cheating that started in  and ended when university officials discovered it in August  PERIOD The cheating involved  classed taken from several departments in the College of Liberal Arts and were done via computer independent study or correspondence work PERIOD

 Alford said PERIOD In addition to the three students who had their degrees taken three others were expelled in  one will be allowed to keep a degree but lose additional credits and another was exonerated and was able to receive a degree PERIOD The expelled students are forbidden from reentering Ole Miss PERIOD

The fulltime staff member involved in the case was fired in August  PERIOD According to Alford that staffer had computer access to students grades and  The students were given improper credit and grades for work they did not do PERIOD

A possible family connection was discovered during the investigation according to Alford PERIOD He said the former instructor and at least a couple of the students involved appear to be related PERIOD

Alford said the matter is now closed and that no further investigation will be conducted PERIOD He also said the university will not pursue the matter in court PERIOD  Alford said 

Smith said the IHL also has no plans for further investigation PERIOD 

Smith said that both Ole Miss and Mississippi State have both been in the news for cheating scandals recently and that 

 Smith said PERIOD 

Alford said that other students should learn from this situation PERIOD
